intro: Styphelia septentrionalis, commonly known as the northern snowbell, is a flowering plant native to the northern regions of North America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heaths and heathers, and is characterized by its low-growing, evergreen shrub form. The plant produces small, bell-shaped white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Styphelia septentrionalis is adapted to cold climates and is an important component of alpine and boreal ecosystems.
